newsitem.title: TAIWAN: HUA NAN RAISES PRIME RATE TO 7.65 PCT.
newsitem.headline: HUA NAN RAISES PRIME RATE TO 7.65 PCT.

text.p: Hua Nan, one of Taiwan's "Big Three" state-run banks, said on Friday it was raising its prime lending rate by 0.125 percentage point to 7.65 percent, effective Saturday.
The bank also was raising its one-month-to-three-year time deposits rates by between 0.05 and 0.20 percentage point.
The bank was taking cue from the First Commercial Bank, another "Big Three" bank, which raised its interest rates on Friday.
The Bank of Taiwan and Cooperative Bank of Taiwan raised their rates on Thursday. Various private commercial banks also raised rates recently.
The rate hikes came one week after the central bank's decision to increase two key interest rates to stabilise the foreign exchange market.
Central bank governor Sheu Yuan-dong said on July 31 the bank was raising the rediscount rate and accommodations against secured loans to 5.25 and 5.625 percent, respectively, effective August 1.
